Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Optomechanics on Multiple Mass Scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Measuring the position of mechanical objects very precisely has several applications in fundamental research as well as in technological devices. In atomic force microscopes (AFM), for example, lasers are used to read out the position of a microscopic cantilever scanning over a surface, with sufficient precision to measure surface variations on the sub-nanometer scale (less than a thousandth of a millionth of a meter--9 zeros past the decimal place). On a completely different size scale, laser light is used to read out the positions of kilogram-scale mirrors of interferometric gravitational wave (GW) detectors with sub-attometer precision (less than a millionth of a millionth of a millionth of a meter--18 zeros past the decimal place). Even though these devices occupy very different scales, they are united by similar principles and limitations to precision position measurement. AFM cantilevers, the mirrors of GW detectors, and indeed a large variety of other mechanical oscillators used as tools of quantum information science, as time keepers, as frequency standards, or as other precision sensors have one thing in common. They all seek to operate at the best precision that quantum mechanics allows. When using laser light to measure the position of a mechanical object, the quantum fluctuations of the light, arising from the discrete nature of photons, imposes a limit on how well one can do. This work explores these quantum limits to position measurement in laboratory experiments that span micro-gram to gram scale mechanical oscillators, with the goal of developing techniques for improving position measurements in general, but also with specific applications to GW detectors.

The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) seeks to detect GWs emitted by violent cosmic events such as supernova explosions and collisions of neutron stars and black holes. Since GWs are completely distinct from electromagnetic radiation, direct detection of GWs is expected to open a new window into the Universe and provide opportunities to study cosmic phenomena that are "invisible" using light alone. GWs from astrophysical sources cause microscopic distortions of spacetime that can be measured by an interferometer whose mirrors are suspended as pendulums to isolate them from all other effects beside the GW. The changes in arm length, typically of order 1e-19 meters (1/10000 the size of a proton!), are detected by very precise measurement of the interference pattern of the laser light reflected from each 4 kilometer long arm of the interferometer. Quantum fluctuations of the light arising from the discrete nature of photons limit the sensitivity of GW detectors. The so-called shot noise, due to the random quantum fluctuations of the light, limits the precision with which the interference pattern, and hence the GW signal, can be measured. Similarly, radiation pressure noise limits the sensitivity due to the interferometer mirrors being "kicked" by the fluctuating momentum of the photons that is transferred to the mirrors when the laser light reflects from them. The proposed experimental program comprises cavity optomechanics experiments with gram- and micro-gram scale mechanical oscillators are aimed at studying several radiation pressure induced phenomena, including direct observation quantum radiation pressure (backaction) noise that is expected to be a major limiting noise source in Advanced LIGO; observation and manipulation of optomechanically induced transparency; observation of ponderomotive squeezing, a promising alternative for generation of squeezed states of light; ground state cooling of macroscopic objects; and reaching and surpassing the free-particle Standard Quantum Limit, which would allow for direct tests of quantum non-demolition measurement techniques. The main purpose of this research is to further the understanding of optomechanical systems in the quantum regime focusing on the features most relevant to GW detectors. Equally attractive is the prospect of exploring the fundamental physics of quantum correlations due to light-mirror couplings in a macroscopic mechanical oscillator system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to use optomechanical coupling to generate squeezed states of light. So what is optomechanical coupling? What are squeezed states of light? What does the one have to with the other?

Optomechanical coupling occurs when light (opto) exerts a force on a movable object (mechanics). In most cavity optomechanical systems, radiation pressure of laser light exerts force and hence drives the motion of a mirror that is part of a mechanical oscillator. Through this coupling, the exquisite quantum properties of the laser light have been used to control the position of the mirror, to optically trap and cool it, and to read out the mirror position.

Light is a quantum entity – it is made of photons. The laws of quantum mechanics dictate that the properties of light must, therefore, be uncertain. Heuristically, quantum uncertainty requires that if we know the amplitude of the light with great precision, we cannot simultaneously know the phase of the light. Laser light has equal quantum uncertainty in both amplitude and phase. A squeezed state is a specially engineered quantum state light where we reduce the uncertainty in one property, e.g the phase of the light, but we must increase the noise in the complementary amplitude property so as to not violate the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. If we make a measurement of phase, as gravitational wave detectors do, we can use a phase squeezed state to improve the precision of that measurement, provided we don’t measure amplitude, which is now noisier. Squeezed states are made by creating quantum correlations between the amplitude and phase properties of laser light.

Optomechanical coupling can be used to create these quantum correlations. When laser light reflects off a movable mirror, amplitude fluctuations of the laser light push the mirror position due to radiation pressure. When the mirror moves in response to the radiation pressure force, that changes the phase of the light reflected from the mirror. The amplitude fluctuations of the light are thus correlated to the phase fluctuations, and the light is squeezed. For this scheme to work, the motion of the mirror oscillator must be made small enough that it moves under the influence of the quantum radiation pressure fluctuation, and not other external forces. The largest extra force noise to overcome is the thermal motion of the mirror oscillator. 

During this award, we achieved two major milestones.  First, we showed that the motion of our mirror oscillator was dominated by quantum radiation pressure noise. Since the motion of the macroscopic mirror was dominated by quantum radiation pressure fluctuations that arise from the quantum electromagnetic vacuum fluctuations, our measurement amounts to observation of a micromirror being buffeted by vacuum states (interacting with the strong optical field). This is a mind-boggling notion: that we can measure the motion of an object being tickled ever so slightly by quantum vacuum fluctuations. By performing this measurement on a mirror visible to the naked eye, at room temperature, and at frequencies that are perceptible to us, we are one step closer to bringing strange quantum effects into the realm of human experience.

Once the mirror motion is dominated by the quantum radiation pressure fluctuations, the light must be squeezed. The second milestone we reached was directly measuring this optomechanically squeezed light. This squeezed light can be used to improve the precision of a wide range of optical measurements, including gravitational wave detectors. An important feature of our experiment is that our mirror oscillator is at room-temperature. It does not entail the complexity and expense of cryogenic cooling, making it well-suited for scaling down to a small footprint, and eventually even to chip size. 

While this work was motivated by the imperative to make ever more sensitive gravitational-wave detectors, it is of wider interest. by creating quantum correlations in room-tempBrature, human-scale systems, we can probe fundamental quantum phenomena and also develop tools for precision optical measurement.
